awd_titl_txt: LTREB Renewal: Long-Term Effects of a Species Invasion on an Aquatic Ecosystem
awd_abstract_narration:
Human activities have moved thousands of species around the world, allowing them to establish populations in new places. These non-native species have large effects on biodiversity and ecosystems, cause enormous economic damage, and are one of the most important and least controlled of human impacts on the world's ecosystems. Scientists know that these effects can change through time, but the amount, timing, and nature of these changes are poorly known. This project will continue a long-term study of the changing impacts of the zebra mussel on the Hudson River ecosystem, an ecologically and economically important invasive species that first appeared in the Hudson River in 1991. This study will improve understanding of one of the world's most problematic invaders in aquatic ecosystems, and provide one of very few detailed studies of the long-term effects on a non-native species. The results of this research will continue to be used by government agencies that manage the Hudson River, and should inform management of non-native species in general. Findings will be disseminated by posting research data on open websites, continuing highly successful educational programs to provide data, lesson materials, and training to middle- and high-school teachers and students in the Hudson Valley and New York City school systems, and continuing an active program of public outreach.

The researchers will continue measuring population parameters (density, mortality rates and size structure) and filtration rates of zebra mussels, phytoplankton biomass, zooplankton density and species composition, bacteria production, water quality parameters (transparency and nutrient concentrations) and particulate and dissolved Carbon to answer the following questions: (1) How will the long-term changes in the zebra mussel population and its effects continue to develop? (2) Can these changes be explained by relationships between the size and characteristics of the zebra mussel population and the Hudson River ecosystem? (3) How does zebra mussel grazing interact with climate to shape properties of the Hudson River ecosystem? The researchers will use time series and regression models to explore zebra mussel population dynamics and the relationship between zebra mussel filtration rates and various components of the river food web. In addition they will analyze three interactions between zebra mussel invasion and climate: 1) effects of freshwater flow on zebra mussel grazing, 2) effects of water temperature and mussel grazing on phytoplankton biomass and 3) correlations between warm temperature and inter-annual variation in zebra mussel mortality. Five additional years of data will allow the researchers to document the remarkable changes that are now occurring in the Hudson River, and substantially increase the power of statistical models to describe these events.

por.por_cntn:
The  purpose of this study was to measure and analyze long-term changes in the Hudson River ecosystem caused by the invasion of zebra mussels. Biological invasions are now one of the most important ways by which human activities affect ecosystems around the world. Although there are good reasons to think that the effects of invasions change through time, these changes have rarely been measured, and are not well understood. Using prior funding from the National Science Foundation and other funders, we observed the appearance of zebra mussels in the Hudson in 1991, the development of a huge population by the end of 1992, and large initial impacts on phytoplankton, zooplankton, bacteria, sediment-dwelling animals, fish, and water chemistry.

But these effects have not been static. First, we found dramatic changes in the zebra mussel population itself. The number of zebra mussels in the Hudson varied about 100-fold from year to year, probably because large adult populations suppress the development of juveniles. In addition, mortality rates of zebra mussels increased dramatically over the course of the invasion, in part because of increased predation from blue crabs. This increased mortality caused the size and age of zebra mussels in the Hudson to fall, but did not affect the number of mussels in the river. We also detected a hint that warming water temperatures may have increased zebra mussel mortality.

Although  quagga mussels, close cousins to zebra mussels, often arrive after zebra mussels and displace them, the appearance of quagga mussels in the Hudson in 2008 had little effect on the Hudson’s zebra mussel population or the ecosystem. In fact, an international group of scientists that we convened to look at long-term changes in zebra mussel populations around the world found surprisingly few generalizations about the long-term behavior of zebra mussel populations that apply to all situations.

Second, some aspects of the Hudson ecosystem (small zooplankton, some sediment-dwelling animals, fish growth rates) have now recovered toward their pre-invasion state. Many other parts of the ecosystem (phytoplankton, large zooplankton, fish abundance) have not recovered, though. The recovery that has occurred appears to be primarily a result of the reduced body size of mussels now in the Hudson - small zebra mussels seem to have smaller effects than large mussels. We also found tantalizing hints that the river’s ecosystem may have become more resistant to zebra mussels.

Our study showed that the effects of biological invasions can change dramatically over the long term, but that the reasons for these changes and the responses of the ecosystem can be complex, and will be difficult to predict.

We disseminated our findings and data widely, including publications in peer-reviewed scientific journals (29 papers and a book over the course of the project), talks at scientific meetings, seminars at colleges and universities, newspaper articles, blogposts, lectures, and public events that reach general audiences, posting our core data on publicly accessible data repositories, and depositing large numbers of biological specimens in publicly accessible museum collections. We worked with educators at the Cary Institute, the American Museum of Natural History, commercial educational companies, and elsewhere to prepare lesson plans, classroom materials, videos and other web-based instructional materials, student-friendly data sets and data visualization tools, and a traveling museum exhibit. These materials have reached thousands of middle- and high-school students and teachers in the Hudson Valley, New York City, and elsewhere. As a result, our findings have been included in many textbooks and scientific review papers about biological invasions and aquatic ecology, and are used by New York State to inform policy and management.
